column12: English Biography
column17: Brill Online Reference Words (Encyclopedia of Jewish in the Islamic, Encyclopedia of the Hebrew Language, Encyclopedia of Judaism)

column12: Rabbi Shelomo ben Yitzhak, best known by the acronym Rashi, authored the most authorative commentaries on the Tanakh and Talmud. He was also a halakhist who authored responsa. Rashi is known as the father of all commentators. There are no extant manuscripts of his works copied prior to his death. Rashi (1040-1105) was an early and very influential medieval Torah and Talmud commentator who lived in France. Rashi's commentary on the Bible is often considered an indispensable tool for Torah study. He described his aim as clarifying the "peshat" or "plain-sense" meaning of each verse.

column27: Four sons, Rabbenu Tam, Rashbam, Isaac ben Meir, Solomon ben Meir

column2: Moshe ben Maimon, Maimonides, Moses Maimonides

column12: Rabbi Moshe ben Nachman authored commentaries on the Torah and the Talmud. He was a halakhist who wrote responsa and stand alone works on Halakhic issues as well as works on mysticism, science and philosophy.  Ramban (d.1270) was a Spanish scholar of Bible, Talmud, and Jewish Law.  Ramban's commentary on the Torah often critiques earlier commentaries, and incoporates Kabbalistic teachings.

Rabbi Sh'muel ben Meir was the grandson of Rashi. He authored a commentary on the Torah that clung strictly to the concept of p'shat sometimes at the expense of received rabbinic traditions. He also wrote a commentary on portions of the Talmud. Rashbam (d. circa 1174) was a French Torah and Talmud commentator. Rashbam's commentary on the Torah provides a detailed "peshat" or "plain-sense" explanation of verse in the Bible.
column27: Had several students cf. Norman Golb

column2: Yonah Gerondi, Yonah ben Abraham Gerondi

column12: Avraham ben Meir was born in Spain but travelled extensively throughout his life. A gifted polymath he wrote an extensive commentary on the torah as well as on grammar, philosophy, astronomy, medicine, and mathematics. His poetry is still read and sung as part of the regular liturgy. Ibn Ezra (d. circa 1167) was a Spanish Torah commentator, who also wrote works on a number of other subjects, including Hebrew grammar and philosophy.  Ibn Ezra's Bible commentary often focuses on grammatical explanations and on the literal meaning of verses.
column27: Several people have the same name as him including the famous Moses Ibn Ezra, but it is disputed if they were related in more modern scholarship. Further research is necesary. He son was Isaac ibn Ezra.

column12: Shlomo Ephraim Luntschitz was the Chief Rabbi of Prague who wrote a commentary on the Torah, Keli Yakar (a precious vessel) as well as a number of other collections of homilies sermons. Rabbi Luntschitz (d. 1619) was a Polish rabbi and orator who is best known for his Torah commentary, Kli Yakar. Keli Yakar is a commentary on the Torah written in a homiletical style.

Rabbi Ovadia ben Yaakov Sforno wrote a commentary on the Torah that sticks to the pshat school. He also wrote works on philosophy and commentaries on a number of books of Tanakh. Sforno is also quoted in responsa of contemporary authorities who consulted him on issues of halakha. Rabbi Ovadiah ben Ya'akov Seforno (d. 1550) was an Italian exegete, philosopher, and physician. Seforno's Torah commentary focuses on the literal meaning of the text, avoids kabbalistic explanations, and sometimes incorporates his knowledge of medicine to help explain verses.

column2: Nissim of Gerona, Nissim ben Reuven

column12: The Tosafists (12th - 13th centuries) are primarily noted for the commentary on the Talmud. Da'at Zekeinim is a Torah commentary that generally provides "peshat" or "straighforward" interpretations of the text.

column2: Raavad, Avraham ben David of Posquières
column21: Moses ben Joseph, Meshullam of Lunel
Rav Nissim Gaon, Hananel ben Hushiel

column12: Rabbi Asher ben Yehiel (d. 1328) was a prominent Talmudist, best known for his summary of laws extracted from the Talmud. He was born in Spain and later moved to Germany. The Rosh's commentary on the Torah was preserved with the commentaries of a number of the Tosafist and included in a collection of those works.
column21: Mazliach ibn al-Basaq, Moses ha-Darshan, Moses Kalfo

column27: Son In law Moses ben Isaac Bonems

column12: Rabbi Chayyim Ibn Atar (d. 1743) was a Moroccan Torah commentator, halakhic decisor, and kabbalist. Or HaChayyim is a Torah commentary which often incorporates Kabbalistic teachings to elucidate the verses of the Bible.

column21: Isaac ben Moses of Vienna,  Yehiel of Paris, Samuel ben Solomon of Falaise, Samuel of Evreux

column12: Rabbi Jacob ben Asher (d. circa 1340) was born in Germany but lived most of his life in Spain. He is most famous for having composed the great law code, Arba'ah Turim. Ba'al HaTurim HaShalem is a commentary on the Torah which draws on the works of other commentators, particularly that of Ramban.

Abarbanel (d. 1508) was a Bible commentator, philosopher, and statesman. Born in Portugal, he lived much of his life in Spain, and died in Venice. Abarbanel's commentary always begins with a number of questions about the text at hand, which he answers over the course of his exegesis.

column2: Meir Levush ben Yehiel Michael Wieser
column4: מאיר ליבוש בן יחיאל מיכל וייזר
column12: Rabbi Meir Leivush Weisser, known as Malbim, (d.1879) was a scholar, orator, and Torah commentator who traveled and lived in a number of locations in Eastern Europe. Malbim is a Torah commentary which attempts to defend the traditional approach to Torah study against the innovations of the Reform movement, and to show that the Oral Law is deeply rooted in the text of the Bible.

column2: David Ben Yosef Kamhi, David Ben Yosef Kimhi
column12: Rabbi David Kimchi (d. 1235) was a French Torah scholar, philosopher, and Hebrew grammarian. Radak's Bible commentary frequently focuses on grammatical and etymological issues within the verses.

Rabbi Meir Simchah of Dvinsk (d.1926) was a Lithuanian rabbi who wrote on issues of Jewish law and Talmud, in addition to his Torah commentary. Meshekh Chochmah is a philosophically-inclined commentary which if often noted for its originality and depth.

Rabbi Chizkiah ben Manoach lived in the thirteenth century, probably in France. The details of his biography are unknown. Chizkuni is a commentary on the Torah which quotes earlier commentators, particularly Rashi, and further explains these comments, as well as the verses they elucidate.

Rabbi Levi ben Gershon (d. 1344) was a French philosopher, mathemetician, astrologer, and Torah commentator. Ralbag's Torah commentary includes an explanation of the words of each section, a commentary on the meaning, and an exploration of the deeper meanings and morals that emerge.

Moshe Alshikh (d. 1593) was a rabbi and orator who was born in the Ottoman Empire and lived in Safed. Moshe Alshikh's Torah commentary, called Torat Moshe, is based on the lectures he gave on the weekly Torah portion. It is a homiletical commentary which extracts moral lessons from the verses.

column2: Bahya ibn Pequdah, Bachya ibn Pekuda
column12: Rabbi Bachya ben Asher (d. circa 1340) was a Spanish Torah scholar and orator who is best known for his Torah commentary.

Rabbi Shimshon Refael Hirsch (d. 1888) was a German scholar, writer and activist. He pioneered a neo-Orthodox movement that championed engagement with Western culture while also maintaining strict observance of Jewish law. Rabbi Shimshon Refael Hirsch's Torah commentary carefully analyzes the language of the Torah and often explains the deeper meanings of commandments.

Rabbi Barukh HaLevi Epstein (d.1941) was a Lithuanian rabbi and scholar, who is best known for his Torah commentary, the Torah Temimah. Torah Temimah is a commentary on the Torah which cites all Talmudic or Midrashic references to a particular verse and provides explanations.

Netsiv (d. 1893) was a Lithuanian rabbi and scholar, and was the head of the prominen Volozhin Yeshiva. HaEmek Davar is a Torah commentary, based on the Netsiv's classes on the weekly Torah portion, which explores the deeper meaning of each verse, and shows how Rabbinic law is closely connected to the Biblical text.
column20: Yitzchok of Volozhin, Yechiel Michel Epstein

column12: Rabbi Yitschak ben Moshe Arama (d. 1494) was a Spanish Talmudist and philosophically-oriented exegete. Akeidat Yitschak is a Torah commentary which is philosophical and also imparts moral and ethical teachings.

Rabbi Yosef Dov Soloveitchik (d. 1892) was a Lithuanian scholar and served as rabbi in a number of communities, culminating in his appointment as rabbi of Brisk. Beit HaLevi is a Torah commentary which ilustrates the connections between Midrash and rabbinic law, and the text of the Torah.

column3: העשיל מקראקא, אברהם יהושע העשל מקראקא
column12: Rabbi Abraham Joshua ben Jacob Heschel (d. 1664) was a Lithuanian scholar and teacher, and later in his life became the head of the yeshiva in Cracow. Chanukkat HaTorah is a commentary on the Torah which gathers earlier rabbinic sayings and uses them to answer questions about each verse.
column27: Brother in law, Zechariah Mendel ben Aryeh Leib,  Samuel ben Uri Shraga Phoebus, Yehezkiah Joshua Feivel Teomim

column12: Rabbi Menachem ben Binyamin Recanati was an Italian kabbalist and halakhic decisor. Recanati's Torah commentary draws upon kabbalistic sources to explain the verses of the Torah.

column2: Aderet Eliyahu, HaGra, Elijah ben Shlomo Zalman from Vilna

column21: Avraham ben Shabtai Sheftel Horowitz, Meir Lublin, Joshua Falk

column12: Rabbi Avraham Saba (d. 1508) was a Spanish teacher and exegete who spent much of his life fleeing persecution. Tseror HaMor is a commentary on the Torah which incorporates mystical explanations from the Zohar.
Rabbi Mecklenberg (d.1865) was a German rabbi and Torah scholar. HaKetav VeHakabbalah is a Torah commentary designed to demonstrate the close connections between Rabbinic law and the Biblical text.

Rabbi Yitschak ben Asher Halevi (11th century) was an early Tosafist who lived in Speyer and was a student of Rashi, the great Talmud and Torah commentator. Riv"a's Torah commentary is preserved in texts from other Tosafists (Talmud commentators) of his time.

Rabbi Hayyim Yosef David Azulai (d. 1806) was a scholar and a prolific writer and publisher. He was born in Jerusalem, and spent much of his life traveling throughout the Jewish communities of Europe.

column2: R. Velvel Soloveitchik, Yizhak Zev Halevi Soloveitchik
column12: Rabbi Yitschak Zev HaLevi Soloveitchik (d. 1959), also known as the "Brisker Rav," was the head of the Brisk Yeshiva in Jerusalem. The Gri"z (which stands for Gaon Rabbi Yitschak Zev) is famous for his conceptual approach to all texts, including in his Torah commentary.
Rabbi Yosef ben Meir Teomim (d.1792) was a Galician halakhist and teacher. He is best known for his legal commentaries on the Shulkhan Arukh, the great sixteenth-century law code.
Rabbi Yitschak Karo (d. 1535) was a Spanish teacher, halakhic decisor, and physician. Toldot Yitschak is a commentary on the five books of the Torah

column2: David ben Josef ben David Abudarham
column4: דוד בן יוסף בן דוד אבודרהם

column12: Rabbi Benno Jacob (d. 1945) was a Reform German rabbi who also had an academic degree in Semitics. Rabbi Benno Jacob's Torah commentary explains each verse in depth in order to show the internal logic of the Torah and to disprove the Documentary Hypothesis.
Rabbi Chayyim Paltiel was a 13th century French Torah commentator.
Rabbi Ovadiah MiBartenura (d. circa 1515) was an Italian scholar who was most famous for his Mishnah commentary. Rabbi Ovadiah MiBartenura's Torah commentary elucidates Rashi's comments on the Torah.

Rabbi Eliyahu Mizrachi (d. circa 1525) was a talmudist and halakhic decisor who served as Chief Rabbi of the Ottoman Empire. Sefer HaMizrachi is a supercommentary on Rashi's Torah commentary, which explains Rashi's sources and elucidates his comments.

Rabbi David Altshul was an 18th century Torah commentator. Metsudat David is a commentary on Prophets and Writings that is designed to help the reader understand the meaning of the text. Metsudat Tsion is essentially a dictionary for difficult words in the Bible; the words are listed and translated.

Rabbi Yedidiah Solomon ben Abraham Nortsi (d. 1626) was an Italian rabbi and Biblical scholar. Minchat Shai is a critical commentary of the Bible which presents all of the variant readings from within Rabbinic literature.

Yaakov ben Yaakov Moshe Lorberbaum of Lissa, Ba'al HaChavat Da'at, Ba'al HaNesivot
